title: Superparamagnetic Iron Oxide-Enhanced Magnetic Resonance Imaging in a Case of Spleen Hamartoma
patient: An ultrasound examination of a 63-year-old female patient presenting with a diffuse pain in the abdomen revealed a 5 × 4 cm solid lesion in the spleen. Her hemoglobin, the number of white blood cells and platelets were normal. Urine and hepatic function tests were also normal. MRI of the abdomen showed a 5 × 5 × 4 cm well-defined solid mass with isointensity on T1-weighted images. The lesion demonstrated a diffuse heterogeneous enhancement on early images obtained after the administration of gadopentetate dimeglumine (Magnevisth, Bayer Schering, Germany) contrast medium at a flow rate of 10 ml/15 s and became more uniformly enhanced on the portal venous phase and hepatic parenchymal phase (fig. ) on T1-weighted images. The lesion showed mild hypointensity on T2-weighted images. MRI study with biphasic infusion (2 ml/min for 10 min and 4 ml/min for 20 min) and at a dose of 15 mmol Fe/kg of glucose 5% ferumoxide (Endoremh, Guerbet, France) contrast agent demonstrated a splenic lesion with a decreased signal intensity on a T2-weighted half-Fourier acquisition single-shot turbo spin-echo (HASTE) image which is the same intensity as liver parenchyma (fig. ). A 3-year follow-up showed no change in the dimensions or other characteristics of the lesion.
